subject: Re: [junit] JUnit dynamic testing with file modifications
msgSnippet: ... It sounds like you have this situation: a bunch of tests are essentially the same, except for the input data and expected output data (called fixture
messageBody:
areinmeyer@... wrote:

> My problem is this. Before development moves along much further, I
> would like to take the test harnesses for each object and remove the
> hardcoding from them. Each test harness should still be able to be
> run individually as it's own test, but I'm looking to the future as
> well, when we have the potential to do nightly builds and will want to
> run all of the test harnesses as a suite together. This definitely
> cannot happen if any hardcoding exists, but there needs to be some
> external way to pass each object the information specific to it only
> to test. I don't want to create a properties/configuration file for
> each object, as many of of the objects can re-use the same sdf file,
> logger, and other config files.
>
> Any suggestions?

It sounds like you have this situation: a bunch of tests are essentially
the same, except for the input data and expected output data (called
"fixture data"). There are two different solutions, depending on your
style of testing.

1. Write one test that loops over all the data.

In xUnit pseudocode, you have this:

testTheBigAlgorithm
foreach (row in testFixtures)
doTest(row)

doTest(row)
// Put the real test in here, using data from row

Here, 'testFixtures' is a collection of objects, each containing your
input data and expected output data.

PROS: Simple and effective.
CON: If the test fails for row 5 of your fixture data, the remaining
tests don't run

2. The Parameterized Test Case pattern.

Write a custom suite() method that builds a suite of tests, each test
with a row of your fixture data. To do this, you need to add a
constructor to your subclass of TestCase that'll accept the fixture data
as a parameter:

class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
private MyTestCaseFixture fixture;

public MyTestCase(MyTestCaseFixture fixture) {
this.fixture = fixture;
}

protected void runTest() {
// Put the real test in here, using data from 'fixture'
}

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("My Tests");

foreach (row in testFixtures) {
suite.addTest(new MyTestCase(row));
}

return suite;
}
}

The method suite() contains some pseudoJava, but I think you know what I
mean.

In either case, you can always write code to retrieve the fixture data
from an external source, like a file or a relational database.

I hope this helps you out. Does it?
